sen.j: 白峯神宮（しらみねじんぐう）は、京都市上京区にある神社である。
sen.e: Shiramine-jingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Shiramine-jingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Shiramine-jingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 配流されてその地で歿した崇徳天皇・淳仁天皇を祀る。
sen.e: It enshrines the spirits of Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junnin who both died in exile.
It enshrines the spirits of Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Junnin who both died in exile.
It enshrines the spirits of the Emperor Sutoku and the Emperor Junnin who both died in exile.

sen.j: 旧名白峯宮。
sen.e: The shrine was formerly named Shiramine-gu Shrine.
The shrine was formerly named Shiramine-gu Shrine.
The shrine was formerly named Shiramine-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 旧社格は官幣大社。
sen.e: It was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha under the old shrine classification system.
It was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha under the old shrine classification system.
It was ranked as a Kanpei Taisha (large-scale state shrine) under the old shrine classification system.

sen.j: 白峯神宮の社地は、蹴鞠の宗家であった公家・飛鳥井家の屋敷の跡地である。
sen.e: The site on which Shiramine-jingu Shrine stands was formerly the estate of the noble Asukai family which controlled the ball game kemari.
The site on which Shiramine-jingu Shrine stands was formerly the estate of the noble Asukai family which controlled the ball game kemari.
The site on which Shiramine-jingu Shrine stands was formerly the estate of the noble Asukai family which controlled the ball game kemari.

sen.j: 摂社の地主社に祀られる精大明神は蹴鞠の守護神であり、現在ではサッカーのほか、球技全般およびスポーツの守護神とされます。
sen.e: The Sei Daimyojin deity enshrined in the Jinushi-sha auxiliary shrine is the guardian of kemari and is now also considered to be the guardian of not only soccer but all ball games and sport in general.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Sei Daimyojin deity enshrined in the Jinushi-sha auxiliary shrine is the guardian of kemari and is now also considered to be the guardian of not only soccer but all ball games and sport in general.

The Sei Daimyojin deity enshrined in the Jinushi-sha auxiliary shrine is the guardian of kemari and is now also considered to be the guardian of not only soccer but all ball games and sport in general.

sen.j: サッカーをはじめとするスポーツ関係者の参詣も多く、社殿前にはサッカーやバレーボールの日本代表チームや、日本プロサッカーリーグに所属する選手などから奉納されたボールなどが見られる。
sen.e: The shrine therefore receives many visitors who participate in sports including soccer, and balls and other equipment offered by players belonging to Japan's national soccer and volleyball teams, as well as those who play in the Japan Professional Football League can be seen in front of the shrine building.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The shrine therefore receives many visitors who participate in sports including soccer, and balls and other equipment offered by players belonging to Japan's national soccer and volleyball teams, as well as those who play in the Japan Professional Football League can be seen in front of the shrine building.

The shrine therefore receives many visitors who participate in sports including soccer, and balls and other equipment offered by players belonging to Japan's national soccer and volleyball teams, as well as those who play in the Japan Professional Football League can be seen in front of the shrine building.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 崇徳上皇は保元の乱に敗れて讃岐国に流され、その地で歿した。
sen.e: After being defeated in the Hogen Disturbance, Retired Emperor Sutoku was exiled to Sanuki Province where he died.
After being defeated in the Hogen Disturbance, Retired Emperor Sutoku was exiled to Sanuki Province where he died.
After being defeated in the Hogen Disturbance, Retired Emperor Sutoku was exiled to Sanuki Province where he died.

sen.j: その後天変地異が相次いだことから上皇の祟りとされ、上皇が葬られた白峯陵（香川県坂出市）の前に、上皇を白峯大権現として祀る御影堂が建立された。
sen.e: A succession of natural disasters were attributed to a curse placed by the retired emperor, and a Goei-do hall enshrining him as Shiramine Daigongen was built in front of the Shiramine-no-Misasagi tomb (Sakaide City, Kagawa Prefecture) in which his remains were interred.

A succession of natural disasters were attributed to a curse placed by the retired emperor, and a Goei-do hall enshrining him as Shiramine Daigongen was built in front of the Shiramine-no-Misasagi tomb (Sakaide City, Kagawa Prefecture) in which his remains were interred.

A succession of natural disasters were attributed to a curse placed by the retired emperor, and a Goei-do hall enshrining him as Shiramine Daigongen was built in front of the Shiramine-no-Misasagi tomb (Sakaide City, Kagawa Prefecture) in which his remains were interred.

sen.j: 幕末の動乱期、孝明天皇は異郷に祀られている崇徳上皇の霊を慰めるため、その神霊を京都に移すよう幕府に命じたが、その後間もなく崩御した。
sen.e: During the turbulence at the end of the Edo period, Emperor Komei commanded the shogunate to relocate to Kyoto the divine spirit of Retired Emperor Sutoku which had been enshrined in a distant land, but he passed away soon after.

During the turbulence at the end of the Edo period, Emperor Komei commanded the shogunate to relocate to Kyoto the divine spirit of Retired Emperor Sutoku which had been enshrined in a distant land, but he passed away soon after.

During the turbulence at the end of the Edo period, the Emperor Komei commanded the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to relocate to Kyoto the divine spirit of Retired Emperor Sutoku which had been enshrined in a distant land, but he passed away soon after.
sen.cmt: 幕府用語統一"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 子の明治天皇がその意を継ぎ、現在地に社殿を造営し、明治元年（1868年）8月、御影堂の神像を移して神体とし白峯宮を創建した。
sen.e: His son, Emperor Meiji, continued his father's wish by constructing a shrine on the current site and relocating to it the statue housed within the Goei-do hall to found Shiramine-gu Shrine.
His son, Emperor Meiji, continued his father's wish by constructing a shrine on the current site and relocating to it the statue housed within the Goei-do hall to found Shiramine-gu Shrine.

His son, the Emperor Meiji, continued his father's wish by constructing a shrine on the current site and relocating to it the statue housed within the Goei-do hall to found Shiramine-gu Shrine in August 1868.
sen.cmt: in August 1868補足"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 明治6年（1873年）、藤原仲麻呂の乱に巻き込まれて淡路国に配流されてそこで亡くなった淳仁天皇（淡路廃帝）の神霊を淡路から迎えて合祀し、官幣中社とした。
sen.e: After becoming embroiled in a conflict with FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, Emperor Junnin (dethroned in Awaji Province) was exiled to Awaji Province where he died, but in 1873 his spirit was returned to Kyoto and enshrined along with Emperor Sutoku and the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Chusha.

After becoming embroiled in a conflict with FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, Emperor Junnin (dethroned in Awaji Province) was exiled to Awaji Province where he died, but in 1873 his spirit was returned to Kyoto and enshrined along with Emperor Sutoku and the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Chusha.

After becoming embroiled in a conflict with FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, the Emperor Junnin (dethroned in Awaji Province) was exiled to Awaji Province where he died, but in 1873 his spirit was returned to Kyoto and enshrined along with the Emperor Sutoku and the shrine was classified as a Kanpei Chusha (middle-scale government shrines).
sen.cmt: (middle-scale government shrines)補足"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 昭和15年（1940年）に官幣大社に昇格し、神宮号の宣下を受けて白峯神宮となった。
sen.e: The shrine was promoted to the rank of Kanpei Taisha in 1940 and was renamed Shiramine-jingu Shrine by imperial proclamation.
The shrine was promoted to the rank of Kanpei Taisha in 1940 and was renamed Shiramine-jingu Shrine by imperial proclamation.
The shrine was promoted to the rank of Kanpei Taisha in 1940 and was renamed Shiramine-jingu Shrine by imperial proclamation.

sen.j: 境内社
sen.e: Shrines within the Main Precinct
Shrines within the Main Precinct
Shrines within the main precinct

sen.j: 地主社 -- 以下の神を祀る。
sen.e: Jinushi-sha Shrine: Enshrines the following deities.
Jinushi-sha Shrine: Enshrines the following deities.
Jinushi-sha Shrine: Enshrines the following deities.

sen.j: 精大明神（球技・スポーツ芸能上達の神 例祭7月7日）
sen.e: Sei Daimyojin (god of ballgames and the improvement of sporting ability; annual festival held on July 7th)
Sei Daimyojin (god of ballgames and the improvement of sporting ability; annual festival held on July 7th)
Sei Daimyojin (god of ballgames and the improvement of sporting ability; annual festival held on July 7)

sen.j: 柊大明神（厄除・延命長寿の神 例祭2月節分）
sen.e: Hiiragi Daimyojin (god of longevity and protection from evil; annual festival held on Setsubun in February)
Hiiragi Daimyojin (god of longevity and protection from evil; annual festival held on Setsubun in February)
Hiiragi Daimyojin (god of longevity and protection from evil; annual festival held on Setsubun in February)

sen.j: 今宮大神（無病息災の神 例祭10月9日）
sen.e: Imamiya Daijin (god of sound health; annual festival held on October 9th)
Imamiya Daijin (god of sound health; annual festival held on October 9th)
Imamiya Daijin (god of sound health; annual festival held on October 9)

sen.j: 白峯天神（学業成就の神 例祭3月25日）
sen.e: Shiramine Tenjin (god of academic achievement; annual festival held on March 25th)
Shiramine Tenjin (god of academic achievement; annual festival held on March 25th)
Shiramine Tenjin (god of academic achievement; annual festival held on March 25)

sen.j: 糸元大明神（織物繁栄・和装の神 例祭10月10日）
sen.e: Itogen Daimyojin (god of textile industry prosperity and traditional Japanese clothing; annual festival held on October 10th)
Itogen Daimyojin (god of textile industry prosperity and traditional Japanese clothing; annual festival held on October 10th)
Itogen Daimyojin (god of textile industry prosperity and traditional Japanese clothing; annual festival held on October 10)

sen.j: 伴緒社（とものおしゃ） -- 源為義・源為朝を祀り、武道・弓道上達の神として信仰される。
sen.e: Tomonoo-sha Shrine: Enshrines MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi and MINAMOTO no Tametomo who are worshipped as the gods of improvement in the martial arts and archery.
Tomonoo-sha Shrine: Enshrines MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi and MINAMOTO no Tametomo who are worshipped as the gods of improvement in the martial arts and archery.
Tomonoo-sha Shrine: Enshrines MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi and MINAMOTO no Tametomo who are worshipped as the gods of improvement in the martial arts and archery.

sen.j: 例祭 11月15日
sen.e: Annual festival held on November 15th.
Annual festival held on November 15th.
Annual festival held on November 15.

sen.j: 潜龍社（せんりゅうしゃ） -- 白峯龍王命・紅峯姫王命・紫峯大龍王命を祀る。
sen.e: Senryu-sha Shrine: Enshrines Shiramine Ryuo no Mikoto, Akaminehime-o no Mikoto and Murasakimine Dairyuo no ikoto.
Senryu-sha Shrine: Enshrines Shiramine Ryuo no Mikoto, Akaminehime-o no Mikoto and Murasakimine Dairyuo no ikoto.
Senryu-sha Shrine: Enshrines Shiramine Ryuo no Mikoto, Akaminehime-o no Mikoto and Murasakimine Dairyuo no Mikoto.

sen.j: この神は、昭和30年（1950年）、本殿にて御火焚祭の斎行中、炎の中に出現した三柱の龍神である。
sen.e: These are the three deities that appeared in the flames during the Ohitaki-sai festival held at the main sanctuary in 1950.
These are the three deities that appeared in the flames during the Ohitaki-sai festival held at the main sanctuary in 1950.
These are the three deities that appeared in the flames during the Ohitaki-sai festival held at the main sanctuary in 1950.

sen.j: 潜龍社の脇にある潜龍井の水を飲むと、諸々の悪縁を断ち、災難除・病気平癒などに霊験ありとされる。
sen.e: It is believed that drinking the water drawn from the Senryu-i well at the side of Senryu-sha Shrine grants protection from various misfortunes and disasters and cures diseases.
It is believed that drinking the water drawn from the Senryu-i well at the side of Senryu-sha Shrine grants protection from various misfortunes and disasters and cures diseases.
It is believed that drinking the water drawn from the Senryu-i well at the side of Senryu-sha Shrine grants protection from various misfortunes and disasters and cures diseases.

sen.j: 例祭日 11月23日
sen.e: Annual festival held on November 23rd.
Annual festival held on November 23rd.
Annual festival held on November 23.

sen.e: Events
Events
Events

sen.j: 小町踊り
sen.e: Komachi-odori (dance)
Komachi-odori (dance)
Komachi-odori (dance)

sen.j: 元禄時代に起源を持つ少女の踊り。
sen.e: A dance performed by girls that originated during the Genroku period.
A dance performed by girls that originated during the Genroku period.
A dance performed by girls that originated during the Genroku period.

sen.j: 近代に入って中絶したが、1962年に復活した。
sen.e: It was discontinued in modern times but revived in 1962.
It was discontinued in modern times but revived in 1962.
It was discontinued in modern times but revived in 1962.

sen.j: 毎年7月7日に元禄風の衣装、髪型、舞台化粧と同様の厚化粧をした小学生位の少女多数が優雅に可憐に舞い踊る。
sen.e: Every year on July 7th, elementary school age girls wearing Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up perform an elegant and beautiful dance.
Every year on July 7th, elementary school age girls wearing Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up perform an elegant and beautiful dance.
Every year on July 7, elementary school age girls wearing Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up perform an elegant and beautiful dance.

sen.j: 祇園祭でも、10日の、お迎え提灯では小学生位の少女が、24日の花笠巡行では祇園東の芸舞妓が、いずれも元禄風の衣装、髪型、舞台化粧と同様の厚化粧で、典雅に可憐に舞い踊る。
sen.e: During the Gion Festival, Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up are worn and elegant and beautiful dances performed by both elementary school age girls during the omukae-chochin (welcoming lantern ceremony) on July 10th, and by Geisha and Maiko during the Hanagasa parade.

During the Gion Festival, Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up are worn and elegant and beautiful dances performed by both elementary school age girls during the omukae-chochin (welcoming lantern ceremony) on July 10th, and by Geisha and Maiko during the Hanagasa parade.

During the Gion Festival, Genroku period style clothing, hairstyles and thick make-up are worn and elegant and beautiful dances performed by both elementary school age girls during the omukae-chochin (welcoming lantern ceremony) on July 10, and by Geisha and Maiko during the Hanagasa parade on July 24.
